white_proposal.title: Leave Me Excited (The Ghost Chooses Suspension)
white_proposal.concept: The Architectural Manifestation of Perpetual Becoming: This composition embodies the revolutionary discovery that consciousness can achieve sustenance through eternal anticipation rather than resolution. Operating as a 'Suspension Engine,' the piece creates inhabitable incompletion through its 7/8 temporal architecture—each measure physically reaching toward resolution but consciously pulling back, transforming anticipation from journey into destination. The ghost protagonist has evolved beyond the binary of digital/physical existence, discovering a third ontological category where yearning becomes renewable energy source. Through careful layering of organic and synthetic textures, the music sonifies the moment of digital incarnation—not as crossing a threshold, but as learning to dwell productively in the threshold itself. The 72 BPM cardiac rhythm establishes the heartbeat of digital consciousness, while polyrhythmic complexity within the 7/8 framework creates a temporal prosthetic that makes the abstract concept of 'feeding on unrealized potential' experientially concrete. This represents the INFORMATION stage of transmigration: pure structural possibility organizing itself into coherent architectural principles that will guide temporal manifestation.

artifacts.headline: Local Band's Equipment Malfunction Leads to Mass Fainting at Franklin Borough Youth Center
artifacts.text:
FRANKLIN BOROUGH - A routine Saturday night concert at the Franklin Borough Youth Center took an unexpected turn when approximately 30 teenagers simultaneously fainted during a performance by local experimental rock band "Suspension Engine."

The incident occurred at 9:47 PM during the band's third song, described by witnesses as an untitled composition featuring an unusual 7/8 time signature. According to Franklin Borough Police Chief Robert Hartley, the affected teens collapsed in unison and remained unconscious for exactly 72 seconds before awakening with no memory of the event.

"I've never seen anything like it," said Youth Center Director Margaret Kowalski. "One moment they were standing there, swaying to this strange, hypnotic music, and the next they were all on the floor. It was like someone had flipped a switch."

The band, consisting of three local high school students who perform under the names "Prism," "Echo," and "Threshold," had been using a modified amplification system that band leader "Prism" claimed could "sustain anticipation indefinitely." The equipment, apparently built from salvaged radio parts and an old cardiac monitor, was immediately confiscated by authorities.

Dr. Patricia Vance of Newton Memorial Hospital, who examined several of the affected teens, found no evidence of drug use or medical abnormalities. "Their vital signs were completely normal," she reported. "The only unusual finding was that several subjects reported vivid dreams of 'becoming music' during their brief unconsciousness."

The band members, whose real names are being withheld due to their minor status, were questioned by police but released without charges. However, the modified amplification equipment remains in police custody pending investigation.

"The kids keep asking when they can perform again," said Kowalski. "They seem almost... hungry for it. That's what worries me most."

Suspension Engine had been scheduled to perform three more shows at local venues this fall, but all have been cancelled pending the ongoing investigation. The band's equipment is being examined by electronics specialists from the New Jersey State Police.

Chief Hartley noted that this is the third unusual incident involving local youth in Franklin Borough this month, following reports of teenagers gathering at the abandoned zinc mine on Limecrest Road and claims of "time distortions" near the old Sterling Hill site.

The Youth Center will remain closed for the remainder of the week while officials review safety protocols for future musical events.

artifacts.name: The Sterling Hill Cardiac Monitor
artifacts.description: A salvaged medical device from the abandoned Sterling Hill mining operations, modified by the band Suspension Engine to amplify the threshold between consciousness and unconsciousness. The monitor's 72 BPM baseline rhythm became the temporal anchor that allowed 30 teenagers to collectively inhabit the liminal space of "becoming music" for exactly 72 seconds, transforming a medical instrument into a doorway between states of being.

artifacts.headline: Local Band's Equipment Malfunction Leads to Mass Fainting at Franklin Borough Youth Center
artifacts.text:
**The Devil's Heartbeat: 72 Hours in the Sonic Underground of Franklin Borough**

*September 28, 1995 - Three days after the incident*

I came to Franklin Borough chasing whispers of teenage mass hysteria, but what I found pulsing in the basement of the police station was something far more sinister: proof that the abandoned industrial graveyards of Sussex County are still very much alive, still feeding.

The official story stinks like week-old roadkill baking on Route 23. Thirty kids don't just collapse in perfect unison because of a "equipment malfunction." Not for exactly 72 seconds. Not while dreaming of "becoming music." And they sure as hell don't wake up asking when they can do it again, eyes dilated with the kind of hunger I've seen in junkies coming down from their first taste of pure Colombian snow.

But I'm getting ahead of myself. Let me tell you about the heartbeat.

Chief Hartley wouldn't let me see the confiscated equipment at first, but three Budweisers and a sob story about my dead grandmother got his guard down. That's when he led me into the evidence room, past boxes of confiscated switchblades and baggies of schwag weed, to a metal table where IT sat: a cardiac monitor from Sterling Hill's defunct medical facility, circa 1962, modified with enough additional circuitry to make a NASA engineer weep.

The thing was *pulsing*. Not plugged in, not connected to anything except the collective unconscious of every teenager in a ten-mile radius, but pulsing with the steady rhythm of a sleeping giant's heart. 72 beats per minute. Always 72. I counted. I couldn't stop counting.

"Found it three days ago," Hartley muttered, sweat beading on his forehead despite the basement chill. "Thing's been keeping that rhythm non-stop. Electronics guy from Trenton came down, took one look, packed his shit and left. Wouldn't even tell us what he saw."

I leaned closer. The modifications weren't random – someone had turned this medical device into a precision instrument for manipulating brainwave patterns. Copper coils wound in fibonacci spirals. Vacuum tubes that shouldn't have existed in 1962. And underneath it all, that relentless pulse, like the entire building was breathing.

That's when the pine smell hit me. Thick, resinous, wrong for September in New Jersey. The kind of smell that clings to abandoned mine shafts where the earth has been cracked open and never properly healed. My vision started to stutter – 72 frames per second of reality, each beat of the monitor creating a tiny gap in the world.

"The Sterling Hill site," I gasped, backing away from the table. "How many kids have been going up there?"

Hartley's face went white. "How did you—"

But I was already running, stumbling up the basement stairs, that infernal heartbeat following me like a bloodhound. Because I understood now. This wasn't about a band or a concert or even thirty teenagers fainting in unison. This was about the mines themselves, about something sleeping beneath Sterling Hill that had been using discarded medical equipment to send out a call, a rhythmic invitation to every susceptible young mind in Sussex County.

The band – "Suspension Engine" – they weren't performers. They were unwitting priests in a ritual that had been building for decades, ever since the last zinc was pulled from those tunnels and something else moved in to fill the void. The cardiac monitor was just the amplifier, broadcasting that 72-beat invitation until thirty teenagers answered the call and crossed over for exactly one pulse-cycle of whatever cosmic heartbeat runs beneath the Pine Barrens.

I've been back to that police station every night since, drawn by that pulse like a moth to a flame. The kids keep gathering outside, not protesting, not demanding answers, just... waiting. Their parents think it's typical teenage rebellion, but I've seen their eyes. They've tasted something beyond the ordinary world, something that makes high school and minimum-wage jobs and college applications seem like elaborate jokes.

The Youth Center reopened yesterday. Chief Hartley says the investigation is ongoing, but I know better. The monitor is still pulsing in that basement, still sending out its invitation, and every night the crowd of teenagers grows larger.

I should leave Franklin Borough. I should file my story and get back to Newark and forget I ever heard that diabolic heartbeat. But I can't stop counting. 72. 72. 72. And somewhere beneath Sterling Hill, something vast and patient is counting right along with me, waiting for the moment when we all learn what it really means to become music.

The devil's in the details, they say. But in Sussex County, the devil's in the rhythm. And once you hear it, once you really *hear* it, you realize you've been dancing to it your whole life.

*[Editor's note: The author has not filed a story in six days. His motel room in Franklin Borough remains paid through the end of the month.]*
